item.content:encoded:
In this post I would like to introduce you to the latest language from python programming, we name it pandas. But before that, let us look at how it can be used for various things.

Pandas is a data manipulation package, specially designed for large-scale numerical data analysis and visualization. It was developed in 2009 by Wes McKinney and his graduate student Julia Sidel and was initially based on R. Pandas has been very beneficial for many different fields of research—from scientific computing to financial finance to machine learning. The primary advantage of using pandas is that it allows users to operate with huge amounts of data without having to worry about memory or storage space. Let’s start our discussion by using pandas for beginners and then move on moving forward.

Pandas help read and write to a few files, which are table-like lists and dictionaries. For example, we can use pandas to read the following file named ‘test.csv’. You need to import pandas after reading the CSV file. So first I will do this firstly, but not only that you need to use this code later, but you also need to import certain packages as well.

The second code is importing ‘NumPy’. Now if you don’t know what is numpy and why we need to import it then follow my article on what is Numpy & How Can We Use It. A brief introduction to numpy and other essential libraries used in the field of Machine Learning.

Now we will try to understand some data that is stored in this CSV file. First, let us create two datasets using pandas.

Let us call the test.csv dataset the x_train dataset and y_train dataset.
